awd_titl_txt: RTG: Coding Theory, Cryptography, and Number Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to enhance the development of students in the fields of coding theory, cryptography, and number theory. Activities with strong vertical integration components are introduced at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels to improve recruitment, retention, and training of students in these areas, including those from historically black colleges and universities and small colleges in the region, and to provide research growth and facilitate professional development for postdocs and early career faculty.  Activities supported by this grant will give broader access to the latest research methods and results in coding theory, cryptography, and number theory, areas replete with theoretical advances and practical applications.

The research problems in this proposal center on automorphic forms and codes, modular forms and algebraic geometry codes, and cryptography and computational number theory. These topics allow entry for students via computation and exploration and offer the opportunity for both theoretical advances and practical applications. Activities in this Research Training Group project include curriculum and condensed research experiences designed to better prepare students transitioning from coursework to research; exam preparation modules to support students entering the graduate school admissions phase as well as those applying for candidacy; and working groups to broaden the research expertise of advanced graduate students and postdocs beyond their dissertation topics in addition to professional development and networking opportunities. The training through research involvement provided by this Research Training Group in Coding Theory, Cryptography, and Number Theory will develop a stronger and more diverse workforce.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RES TRAINING GROUPS IN THE MATH SCIENCES
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The RTG grant at Clemson University was instrumental in advancing research and training in Coding Theory, Cryptography, and Number Theory. Over its tenure, the grant facilitated comprehensive investigations across diverse disciplines, yielding significant contributions to areas such as extremal primes and Frobenius distributions for elliptic curves, locally repairable codes, distributed storage, quantum-error correcting codes, secure distributed and parallel computing, and lattice-based and code-based cryptography among others.

Throughout the duration of the RTG grant, 14 graduate students and 4 postdoctoral fellows received crucial support, enabling them to pursue research. Many of these individuals successfully transitioned into impactful roles within industry, government, and academia immediately after completing their programs. Moreover, the grant extended its reach to 144 undergraduate students, providing them with invaluable summer research experiences, enriching their academic journey and fostering a passion for inquiry.

The tangible outcomes of the grant are substantial, with more than 50 peer-reviewed journal articles or conference proceedings stemming from the research endeavors. These findings were disseminated extensively, being presented at conferences over 140 times. Notably, the grant also facilitated the submission of a patent and a digital signature to NIST, underscoring its impact in advancing technological innovation and security.

Beyond research outputs, the grant allocated resources to facilitate professional development and networking opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Support for conference attendance enabled individuals to engage with peers and senior colleagues, fostering collaboration and knowledge exchange. Additionally, summer grant funding provided essential research time, allowing participants to delve deeper into their projects and make meaningful progress.

Moreover, the impact of the grant extended beyond its immediate scope, playing a pivotal role in establishing a school-funded postdoctoral program at the School of Mathematical and Statistical Sciences of Clemson University. This enduring legacy underscores the grant's lasting contribution to the academic landscape, laying the foundation for continued excellence in research and education.

 


Last Modified: 03/22/2024
Modified by: Felice Manganiello
